questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presented with progressive, painless loss of vision in the right eye. There was no history of associated photopsia. On examination, a shifting fluid sign is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the presence of shifting fluid is suggestive of exudative retinal detachment (ED). 

Exudative RD is characterized by the accumulation of fluid beneath the retina in the absence of a retinal break or traction. Fluid leaks outside the vessels and accumulates under the retina. RD does not occur as long as the retinal pigment epithelium is pumping the leaking fluid into the choroidal circulation. 

Causes:

  • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis
  • Choroidal tumors like melanoma
  • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Coats disease

Patients may present with painless progressive visual field defects without photopsia. Floaters may be present if there is an associated vitritis.

Clinical signs include

  • Convex configuration of the retinal detachment, with a smooth surface
  • A detached retina is very mobile
  • Shifting fluid sign - Subretinal fluid causes detachment of the retinal portion under which it accumulates. In the upright position, the fluid collects under the inferior retina. But in the supine position, the inferior retina flattens and the fluid shifts posteriorly, which leads to detachment of the superior retina.
  • The cause of the RD may be apparent. 
  • Leopard spots - Scattered areas of clumped subretinal pigment may be seen after the detachment has flattened.

Retinal detachment (RD) is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium. It is classified into the following:

  • Rhegmatogenous RD - due to a tear or break in the retina
  • Secondary RD - due to some other preceding event
    • Exudative RD
    • Tractional RD

The image shows the shifting fluid sign and late-phase fluorescein angiogram showing hyperfluorescent spots with a leopard spot pattern in the posterior fundus and staining of the arteries and an avascular area in the nasal region, respectively.

Other options:

Option A: Breaks in the Descemet membrane may occur due to

  • Corneal enlargement in infantile glaucoma. Haab striae are horizontal concentric lines representing the breaks in Descemet’s membrane, seen in patients with congenital glaucoma.
  • Deformations such as keratoconus
  • Birth trauma

The image below shows Haab's striae. 

Option B -  Rhegmatogenous RD: In this condition, fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina. The most dangerous type of retinal break is a horseshoe tear. The most dangerous location of the retinal break is the superior temporal retina. Risk factors for the development of rhegmatogenous RD are:

  • High myopia
  • Blunt trauma
  • Previous cataract surgery (aphakia and pseudophakia)
  • Lattice degeneration of the retina

Clinical features of rhegmatogenous RD:

  • Symptoms
    • Photopsia: Flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break. Photopsia is symptom-specific for rhegmatogenous detachment. 
    • Floaters: Due to associated vitreous haemorrhage
    • Visual field defect: A black curtain/veil in front of the eye
  • Signs
    • Shaffer's sign: Pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) are a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
    • The detached retina is convex in its configuration.
    • The surface is corrugated with undulations.

Option C - Tractional RD: It occurs when the vitreous has an abnormally strong attachment to the retina. With vitreous liquefaction and subsequent contraction, the retina is pulled away from the retinal pigment epithelium without a retinal break.

  • Causes
    • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
    • Retinopathy of prematurity
    • Eales' disease
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is concave in its configuration.
    • No breaks are seen.

The image below shows the tractional segments and bands with a concave retina.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man came to the OPD with blurred vision. His fundus examination was done. The fundus appearance is as shown in the image given below. This appearance is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The fundus image shows a Bayoneting sign in the optic disc, which is seen in the advanced stages of glaucoma.

In glaucoma, due to the loss of neuroretinal rim tissue, nasal shifting of retinal vessels occurs, giving the vessels the appearance of being broken off at the margin. This leads to sharp angulation of vessels at the margin of the excavated cup, known as the bayoneting sign.

Glaucomatous changes in the optic disc:

Early glaucomatous changes

  • Slit defects of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Splinter hemorrhages on disc margin
  • Large cup: 0.7 or more
  • Asymmetry of the cups: A difference equal to or more than 0.2 between two eyes is significant
  • Vertical oval cup

Advanced glaucomatous changes

  • Marked cupping (Beanpot cupping)
  • Thinning of neuroretinal rim
  • Bayoneting sign
  • Laminar dot sign

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with blurring of vision and the presence of a dark spot with distorted vision in his right eye for the past week. He has been taking steroid tablets for asthma. His best corrected visual acuity measured 6/24 in his right eye and 6/6 in his left eye. Posterior segment examination is shown in the image. What is the first-line management for this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with visual abnormalities, history of steroid intake, and the fundal image depicting focal fundal detachment are suggestive of central serous retinopathy. Discontinuation of steroid use is the first line of management in this case.

Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSR) is an idiopathic disorder characterized by a localized serous detachment of the sensory retina at the macula.

Recent studies implicate abnormal choroidal circulation as the cause of CSR. 

Risk factors:

  • Age: young adults (20–50 years)
  • Sex: male > female
  • Steroid intake 
  • Emotional stress
  • Pregnancy
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Hypertension
  • Sleep apnea syndrome

Clinical features:

  • Mostly unilateral
  • Retinal detachment - Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Relative positive scotoma
  • Micropsia
  • Metamorphopsia

Investigations:

  • Ophthalmoscopy - circular ring reflex present and foveal reflex absent
  • FFA - enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern
  • OCT - optically empty neurosensory elevation at macular region.

Spontaneous resolution is seen in most cases and hence observation is enough. Steroids are contraindicated. The disease is usually self-limiting but may recur.

Other treatment options for recurrent and chronic cases: Laser photocoagulation, photodynamic therapy, and intravitreal anti-VEGF.

The image below depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/ enlarging dot sign - A small hyperfluorescent spot that gradually enlarges in size - seen in Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR).

The image below depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing smokestack appearance - A small hyperfluorescent spot that ascends vertically like a smokestack that looks like an umbrella or a mushroom - seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

 The image below depicts optical coherence tomography (OCT) showing fluid accumulation in the subretinal space, with shallow retinal detachment - seen in CSR.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college-going student presents to you with a rapidly increasing power of glasses due to progressive myopia. She has a history of persistent eye rubbing. You also noticed the following sign, when the patient was asked to look in a downward gaze. All the following are treatment options for given condition except?

choices.text: Riboflavin drops, followed by exposure to UV-B radiation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and lower lid bulging on downgaze (Munson's sign- as shown in the image) is suggestive of keratoconus. Riboflavin drops, followed by exposure to UV-A radiation (not UV-B), is a treatment modality for this condition.

Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder. It manifests as characteristic cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision.

It is a non-inflammatory disease. With the exception of the significant loss of vision, other classic signs of inflammation are not usually present. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular corneal topography often cause significant myopia and irregular astigmatism. 

Important associations:

  • Rigid contact lens wear
  • Chronic eye rubbing
  • Marfan's, Down’s, EDS syndrome
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta, MVP
  • RP, Leber congenital amaurosis
  • VKC, aniridia, ectopia lentis

Investigations:

  • Corneal topography
  • Pachymetry
  • Keratometry:
    • Steep cornea
    • Bow tie pattern
    • Paracentral thinning of the cornea (thinnest point) 

Treatment:

  • Spectacle correction
  • Rigid gas-permeable contact lens
  • Corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL) - instillation of riboflavin drops to photosensitize the eye, followed by exposure to ultraviolet-A light
  • Intra-corneal ring segments (INTACS)- small curved PMMA ring or set of rings that are implanted in the cornea to help flatten corneal curvature in an effort to improve vision
  • Corneal transplantation- Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty (DALK) and penetrating keratoplasty (PKP)

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic female presents with complaints of progressive pain in and around her left eye. It is associated with the development of multiple vesicles and pustules. These symptoms were preceded by an episode of influenza-like illness a week before. What is the pattern of inflammation seen in the given slit-lamp finding of her eye?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of herpes zoster ophthalmicus and the pattern of inflammation seen in the given slit lamp image is called nummular keratitis.

Nummular keratitis is the earliest finding of the corneal stromal involvement. It is characterised by multiple, fine, granular, coin-shaped infiltrates in the anterior stroma. This condition presents during the second week of the infection and may cause permanent scarring.

●      Punctate epithelial keratitis

●      Pseudodendrite formation (typically smaller than the typical dendrites and lack the terminal end-bulb formation) Lesions due to immune-mediated inflammation:

●      Disciform keratitis (deep stromal infiltrate that develops after 3 to 4 months; has a central disc-shaped affected area) Lesions due to chronic neurotrophic keratopathy:

questions.text: A newborn child presents with the following finding in the right eye as shown in the image below. The left eye is normal. What is the ideal age to take this patient up for elective surgery?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dense unilateral congenital cataract. Ideally, unilateral dense cataract merits urgent surgery and it is at 6 weeks when elective surgery should be performed.

Generally, it is not advisable to operate on lamellar cataracts until the child is 1 or preferably 2 years old. But when the lens is completely opaque, or the pupil will not dilate, and when squint or nystagmus is developing, it is wise to operate at an earlier age. Moreover, the results of surgery in unilateral cataracts in children are universally poor, unless the operation is carried out within the first 6 weeks of birth.

This is because the critical period for developing the fixation reflex in both unilateral and bilateral visual deprivation disorders is between 2 and 4 months of age. Thus, any cataract dense enough to impair vision must be dealt with before this age and the earliest possible time is preferred. 

Surgery involves anterior capsulorhexis, aspiration of lens matter, capsulorhexis of the posterior capsule, limited anterior vitrectomy, and IOL implantation, if appropriate. It is important to correct associated refractive errors.

Related Pearl: Types of Congenital Cataract

Punctate cataract: Blue-dot cataract, most common congenital cataract

 

Zonular/Lamellar cataract: Most common congenital cataract with diminished vision; Spokes of a wheel appearance (Rider’s Cataract) A, B, and C

 

Fusiform/coralliform cataract: Anteroposterior spindle shaped appearance. 

 

Nuclear cataract: Most common type of cataract seen in congenital rubella syndrome

 

Coronary cataract: Appears as a corona of club-shaped opacities near the periphery of the lens.

 

Anterior polar cataract: May arise either due to delayed development of anterior chamber or due to corneal perforation

 

Posterior polar cataract: Progressive form of posterior polar cataract, which typically shows an "onion whorl appearance"

questions.text: The most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery is:
questions.solution:
After-cataract is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery.

After cataract, otherwise known as posterior capsular opacification/ secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. 

Symptoms of after cataract include:

  • Reduction of visual acuity
  • Slowly worsening blurring
  • Glare and occasionally monocular diplopia

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls - present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring - presents as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type - present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 

The illustration given below shows different types of after-cataract.

A posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment. It becomes indicated when the patient is symptomatic. 

Other options: 

Option A: Retinal detachment is an uncommon late complication of cataract surgery. It may occur in people with pre-operative risk factors such as retinal breaks, high myopia, or due to vitreous loss during surgery. Retinal detachment is treated by pars plana vitrectomy.

Option B: Postoperative endophthalmitis is a complication of cataract surgery causing acute and severe intraocular inflammation. Patients complain of pain and visual loss. Clinically, there is eyelid swelling with conjunctival injection, Marcus-Gunn pupil, hypopyon, and vitritis. Intravitreal antibiotics are the key to management. Other treatment modalities include oral antibiotics and steroids, and pars plana vitrectomy.

Option C: Irvine–Gass syndrome is postoperative cystoid macular edema. It is an uncommon late complication of cataract surgery. It is clinically insignificant; resolves on its own.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: At an ophthalmology clinic, you witness the doctor covering one eye of the patient and asking the patient to read the smallest line on the near chart. He then shines a bright light into the eye for 15 seconds and asks the patient to read the same line, noting down the time taken for the patient to recover and read. He repeats the same with the other eye. Choose the correct statement about the test performed.

choices.text: Recovery time is prolonged in macular disease
Recovery time is delayed in normal individuals
Prolonged recovery time in those with optic nerve pathology
Normal recovery time in macular disease

questions.solution:
The test described above is the photostress test, and recovery time is prolonged in macular diseases.

The photostress test is used to differentiate between the disease involving the macula and optic nerve. In this test, one eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on the near chart. A bright light is then shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again, and the time taken to recover is noted. The test is repeated with the other eye.

In normal persons and in patients with optic nerve disease, the recovery time is not affected. Whereas, in patients with macular disease the recovery time is prolonged and is usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time. This is because, in macular disease, the photoreceptors are damaged, and there is a delay in the visual pigment regeneration process.

The test is of particular use in an early macular disease like central serous retinopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of fungal hypopyon?
questions.solution:
Fungal keratitis causes a non-sterile hypopyon.

Unlike bacterial ulcer, the hypopyon may not be sterile as the fungi can penetrate into the anterior chamber without perforation. Aspergillus spp. are the most common cause.

Hypopyon in a fungal ulcer

  • Non-sterile
  • Thick and Fixed
  • Contains fungal filaments

questions.text: The finding in the below-given image is seen in a case of:
questions.solution:
The image findings show Hollenhorst plaques are seen in central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

They are the cholesterol emboli seen in retinal arterioles. The most common cause of CRAO (Central retinal artery occlusion) is embolism.

The outer retina is supplied by the ciliary arteries while the inner retina is supplied by the central retinal artery (CRA). Both sets of arteries are branches of the ophthalmic artery. Arterial occlusion can occur due to atherosclerosis (most cases), inflammation, vasospasm, and hypotension.

The ophthalmic artery is the first branch of the internal carotid artery, so any emboli from the carotid arteries can lead to CRAO. 

The emboli that are refractile, yellow-white in color, and made of cholesterol are called Hollenhorst plaques. Emboli can also be greyish, elongated fibrin-platelet aggregates, or non-scintillating white calcific particles. 

The goal of treatment is to restore blood flow. Antiplatelet therapy, decreasing intraocular pressure with timolol, acetazolamide and mannitol, and thrombolytic can be used. Rebreathing into a paper bag will help increase CO2 and consequently arterial vasodilation. 

Other options: 

Option B - Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) would have fundoscopy features of deep blot and flame-shaped hemorrhages in the posterior and peripheral retina and cotton wool spots.

The below image shows flame-shaped hemorrhages in CRVO.

 Option C - Cystoid macular edema occurs when there is fluid accumulation in the outer plexiform and inner nuclear layers of the retina with cyst-like cavities. It would have fundoscopy features of loss of foveal depression, thickening of the retina, and multiple cystoid areas in the sensory retina. There may be optic disc swelling and a lamellar hole. 

Option D - Central serous retinopathy is characterized by localized serous detachment of the retina at the macula due to leakage from the choriocapillaris. Detachment would be visible on fundoscopy with clear or turbid subretinal fluid, depigment retinal pigment epithelium, and atrophic damage.

questions.text: Identify the yoke muscle for the muscle marked below?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the above image is left superior oblique, hence the corresponding yoke muscle will be right inferior rectus. (Its left eye because of the presence of medial septum to the right to eyeball) 

Yoke muscles are contralateral synergists. They are a pair of muscles, one from each eye, which contracts simultaneously during version movements.

Examples are:

  • Right MR and Left LR
  • Right IO and Left SR

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with redness and photophobia of the left eye was seen in the OPD. An image of a characteristic lesion of her eye is as shown below. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a white-pinkish nodule surrounded by hyperemia on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus with associated symptoms of redness and photophobia most likely has phlyctenular conjunctivitis. The given finding is referred to as a phlycten.

 Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction due to endogenous allergens like Staphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

It is characterized by the following:

  • Phlycten that may eventually form ring ulcers
  • Shallow marginal ulcer due to the breakdown of limbal phlycten known as scrofulous ulcer
  • Fascicular ulcer with a prominent parallel leash of blood vessels that heals leaving a band-shaped opacity

Treatment: Topical steroids; atropine if the cornea is involved.

Note: This can be differentiated from pinguecula by the following points:

Pinguecula is a yellow triangular patch on the conjunctiva near the limbus. It usually remains free from conjunctival congestion.  The following image shows a yellow patch with tortuous blood vessels. There is no congestion as seen with a phlycten.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with headache. He also has a family history of glaucoma. On examination, intraocular pressure was 23 and 24 mmHg in the right and left eye respectively. Iridocorneal angles were normal on gonioscopy. There was no visual field defects. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition of the patient? (POAG- Primary open-angle glaucoma)

choices.text: Thin cornea is a risk factor for POAG development
Reducing IOP is effective in delaying the onset of POAG
Increased cup disc ratio is a risk factor for POAG development
Younger people are more at risk for progression to POAG than older people

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the patient points towards ocular hypertension. Older people are more at risk of progression than younger people.

Ocular hypertension (OHT) is characterized only by raised intraocular pressure (IOP). The optic disc and visual fields are normal, with no evidence of angle closure.

Significant risk factors for the progression of ocular hypertension to primary open-angle glaucoma include the following:

  • Increased IOP
  • Increasing age
  • Increased cup-disc ratio
  • Thin cornea 
  • African-American race
  • Male gender
  • Associated heart disease

Evaluating the option statements on their own merit can help rule out the other 3 options and arrive at the correct answer, irrespective of solving the clinical scenario. At times, the clinical scenario may not really be essential to arriving at the answer.

questions.text:
As a part of the pre-operative evaluation of a patient posted for cataract surgery, you are asked to calculate the power of the intraocular lens to be implanted. What investigations would you perform?
  1. Biometry
  2. Pachymetry
  3. Tonometry
  4. Keratometry
  5. Gonioscopy
questions.solution:
The investigations commonly performed for calculating the power of the intraocular lens (IOL) include biometry and keratometry. 

The power of an intraocular lens (IOL) is calculated using a biometer, a procedure called biometry. Keratometry involves determining the curvature of the anterior corneal surface (the steepest and flattest meridians), and it is expressed in dioptres or millimetres of radius of curvature.

Optical coherence biometry is a noncontact method of measuring axial length. Modern biometry devices also perform keratometry, anterior chamber depth, and corneal measurement and can calculate IOL power using a range of formulas. 

 The most common method of determining IOL power uses a regression formula called the SRK formula, which is given below:

 P = A - 2.5L - 0.9K

Where, 

  • P is the power of IOL
  • A is a constant, which is specific for each lens type
  • L is the axial length of the eyeball in millimeters, determined by using the A-scan ultrasonography
  • K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry.

 The images given below show a biometer and a keratometer, respectively.  

A-scan ultrasonography is used for determining the axial length of the eyeball. It can be acquired by direct contact or by using a water bath over the eye (immersion ultrasonography). Unfortunately, it is a slightly less accurate method of determining the axial dimension.

The sound beam must be aligned with the visual axis for maximal precision. Each reflecting surface is represented by a spike on the oscilloscope monitor. A-scan ultrasonography is shown in the image below.

Other options: 

Pachymetry measures corneal thickness. It is shown in the image below.

Tonometry measures intraocular pressure. It is shown in the image below.

Gonioscopy is used to visualize the angle of the anterior chamber. It also aids in the localization of the foreign body, abnormal blood vessels, or tumors in the angle. The given instrument below is an indirect gonioscope.

Related Pearl: Important investigations related to the cornea

  • Pachymetry: To measure corneal thickness
  • Keratometry: To measure corneal curvature (of the anterior surface)
  • Corneal topography: To measure corneal curvature, shape, and thickness
  • Specular microscopy: To assess the corneal endothelium
  • Anterior segment ocular coherence tomography: To assess different corneal layers

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a dense cataract has been posted for cataract surgery. Since fundus examination was not possible due to dense cataract, the surgeon advises getting an electrophysiological test to assess the retinal function. The record obtained is as shown below. Which of the following waves represent the metabolic activity of pigment epithelium?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a normal electroretinogram(ERG). The metabolic activity of pigment epithelium is represented by a C wave.

Electroretinography (ERG) is the record of changes in the resting potential of the eye induced by the stimulation of a flash of light.

Waves of normal ERG

  • a-wave is a negative wave possibly representing the activity of rods and cones
  • b-wave is a large positive wave that is generated by Muller cells. They represent the activity of the bipolar cells
  • c-wave is a positive wave representing the metabolic activity of pigment epithelium

ERG is used in the diagnosis and prognosis of retinal disorders like retinitis pigmentosa, Leber’s congenital amaurosis, retinal ischemia, and other chorioretinal degenerations.

It helps to assess retinal function when fundus examination is not possible like in the presence of dense cataracts and corneal opacity. It is also used to assess the retinal function of the children where possibilities of impaired vision are considered.

A subnormal B wave is seen in early cases of retinitis pigmentosa. 

An extinguished response is seen when there is complete failure of rod and cone function in advanced retinitis pigmentosa, complete retinal detachment, and central retinal artery occlusion. 

A negative response is seen when there is gross disturbances of retinal circulation.

questions.text: An ophthalmologist performs the swinging flashlight test, which reveals the findings as shown in the image given below. Which structure is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image above shows Marcus Gunn pupil, which is confirmed by the swinging-flashlight test. The right eye is affected, while the left eye is normal. It is the earliest sign of optic nerve/cranial nerve II disease.

The flashlight is swung to and fro and the pupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils remain constricted. In the presence of relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), both pupils dilate on moving the flashlight from the normal to the abnormal eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil.

Impaired pupillary constriction due to a defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye, causes a RAPD or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test. 

The image given below shows the swinging flashlight test as seen in a normal person and in a patient with a right relative afferent pupillary defect.

Other abnormal pupillary reactions:

  1. Amaurotic light reflex - On flashing light to the affected eye, there is no direct light reflex in the affected eye, and there is no consensual light reflex in the normal eye. This occurs due to a lesion in the optic nerve or retina.
  2. Efferent pathway defect - Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side and presence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the normal side. It occurs due to a defect in the efferent pathway.
  3. Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil -In this condition, light reflex (ipsilateral direct and contralateral consensual) is absent when light is thrown on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and nasal half of the normal side, while it is present when the light is thrown on the nasal half of the affected side and temporal half of the normal side. It occurs due to a lesion in the optic tract.
  4. Adie’s tonic pupil - In this condition, the light reflex is absent and the response to near reflex is very slow and tonic. The affected pupil is larger than normal (anisocoria). It is caused by postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

questions.text:
Mr. Ramesh is a 55-year-old man who has pledged for cornea donation. History of which of the following diseases would render his cornea unfit for transplantation?
  1. Hypertension
  2. COVID-19 Infection
  3. Leprosy
  4. Diabetes mellitus
  5. Tetanus
questions.solution:
Diabetes and hypertension are not considered as a contraindication for carrying out cornea donation.

Contraindications for eye donation include Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, HIV, syphilis, leprosy, tetanus, and COVID-19.

In view of the recent pandemic, COVID -19 has also been included as a contraindication for eye donation as per the eye bank 2020 guidelines.

Contraindications for transplantation: These include conditions with a potential risk of transmission of local or systemic communicable disease from donor to recipient.

  • Death of unknown cause.
  • Death with progressive neurodegenerative diseases like
    • Chronic idiopathic demyelinating polyneuropathy
    • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
    • Multiple sclerosis
    • Huntington’s chorea
    • Alzheimer’s disease
    • Myasthenia gravis
    • Parkinson’s syndrome
    • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
  • Active meningitis, viral encephalitis
  • Active septicemia at the time of death
  • Active viral hepatitis
  • Congenital rubella
  • Reye’s syndrome
  • Suspected rabies and persons who, within the past six months, were bitten by an animal suspected to be infected with rabies
  • Active miliary tuberculosis
  • Hepatitis B surface antigen-positive donors, Hepatitis C seropositive donors
  • HTLV-I or HTLV-II infection
  • HIV seropositive donors
  • Active syphilis or seropositive for syphilis.
  • Leprosy
  • COVID-19 infection
  • Tetanus

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of diplopia, restricted eye movements, and inability to close the lids of his left eye. He previously sustained chemical burns to the same eye. On examination, the eye appears as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of diplopia, lagophthalmos, restricted eye movements with a history of chemical burns to the same eye and the image shown indicates a diagnosis of symblepharon.

It refers to the partial or complete adhesion of the palpebral conjunctiva to the bulbar conjunctiva. These adhesions occur when raw surfaces on two opposed areas of the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva remain in contact as they heal. The raw surfaces appear following chemical injuries, burns, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, ulcers, diphtheria, ocular pemphigus or eye surgeries.

Most patients present to resolve the cosmetic disfigurement caused as a result of this condition but can also have restricted eye movements, resulting in diplopia and an inability to close the lids, i.e. lagophthalmos.

When the bands of fibrous tissue subsequently formed between the lid and the globe involve the fornices, it is called symblepharon posterior. When they are present anteriorly, it is called symblepharon anterior. Sometimes, the lids may be completely adherent to the globe, in a condition called total symblepharon.

This condition is mostly managed surgically. The attachments are released and the raw areas are covered with a conjunctival, buccal mucous membrane or amniotic membrane grafts. A therapeutic contact lens or symblepharon ring may also be used to separate the raw surfaces.

The prevention of symblepharon by the early and frequent use of a glass rod or therapeutic bandage contact lens is of the utmost importance.

Other options:

Option A: Ankyloblepharon involves the presence of adhesions between the margins of the two lids.

Option B: Blepharophimosis is a condition where the palpebral fissure appears to be smaller than normal.

Option D: Ectoprion refers to the outward turning of the lid margin. Patients present with epiphora as the primary symptom, especially when the lower lid is involved. Other symptoms include local irritation, discomfort and mild photophobia when associated with chronic conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presented with complaints of left eye pain. She has a previous history of vitreoretinal surgery with tamponade for management of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment in the left eye 2 years ago. Her left eye is shown below. What is the finding shown in the image?

choices.text: Collection of pus in the vitreous
Collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber

questions.solution:
The image shows reverse hypopyon/ inverse hypopyon/ hyperoleon, which is the collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber.

Silicone oil is the vitreous substitute that is injected into the vitreous cavity after vitrectomy. When it gets emulsified, it enters the anterior chamber and collects in the upper part.

Complications of silicone oil in the anterior chamber:

  1. Glaucoma
  2. Band-shaped keratopathy

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden painless loss of vision in his right eye. On fundus examination, the following finding was seen. Which among the following conditions is likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows a splashed sauce appearance which is characteristic of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). 

CRVO refers to sudden or acute occlusion of the central retinal vein. It presents with a sudden loss of vision. On examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is present.

Funduscopy shows engorged and tortuous retinal veins, massive retinal hemorrhages with splashed tomato appearance, and cotton wool spots. The disc is edematous and hyperemic. Changes that occur later include neovascularization at the disc or periphery with pigmentary changes at the macula.

Complications:

  • Rubeosis iridis or neovascularization of the iris
  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) or 100 day glaucoma
  • Vitreous hemorrhage

100-day glaucoma is a type of neovascular glaucoma (NVG) and is so-called because it typically develops 3 months after the episode of CRVO.

Other options:

Option A- The funduscopy findings in central retinal artery occlusion include pale retina, thread-like arteries, a cherry-red spot in the macula, and cattle trucking (segmentation of blood in the retinal veins). It is shown below.

Option C: The funduscopy in retinal detachment shows detachment of fovea and macula, as shown below.

Option D: Fundoscopy changes in retinitis pigmentosa include perivascular retinal hyperpigmentation, narrow retinal arterioles, atrophy of retinal pigment epithelium, and disc pallor. It is shown below.

questions.text: A person is brought to the emergency department following a blast. On investigation, a small metallic foreign body is found entrapped in the lens of his right eye. What is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
For a patient with a foreign body in the lens, the best treatment option is complete removal of the lens.

If a foreign body lies within the lens, it is better to treat such particles as if they were non-magnetic or to remove the lens as a whole. For a non-magnetic foreign body:-

  • The foreign body on iris it can usually be picked out by an iris forceps through a suitably placed keratome incision. If entangled an iridectomy is performed.
  • If the foreign body is in the lens, a few days should be allowed to elapse for the aqueous to act upon the lens fibers. Aspiration is then performed and the foreign body is removed with the lens matter.
  • If the foreign body lies on the retina, and if accurate localization has been attained, it is removed directly by intra-vitreal forceps as part of a complete vitrectomy. Laser photocoagulation of the surrounding retina is also done to prevent a late retinal detachment.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female patient reports painless decreased vision in her left eye associated with a “black spot” close to the center of her vision for 2 months. Peripheral vision is normal. Her medical history includes hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. On examination, her visual acuity is significantly reduced in both eyes (left more than right). Amsler grid test shows wavy lines in the central part of the grid. Fundus examination revealed the following findings. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests painless progressive visual loss over months, central scotoma, and the fundoscopic image show sub-retinal hemorrhage near the macula. These features are suggestive of exudative/wet age-related macular degeneration.

In dry/non-exudative age-related macular degeneration, the progression is much slower, over decades. The fundoscopic image would show multiple drusens in the macular area for early dry AMD. For intermediate dry AMD, drusen may appear confluent with significant pigment changes and pigment accumulation. 

The image below shows Drusens in the macular area in Dry macular degeneration.

Age-related macular degeneration (AMD), a degenerative disorder of the macula, is characterized by the presence of drusen and RPE changes. It is the most common cause of permanent central visual loss in the elderly.

Risk factors:
  • Age
  • White race
  • Family history
  • Smoking
  • Hypertension
  • Cardiovascular diseases
  • Obesity
  • Aspirin intake 

Dry (non-exudative, non-neovascular) AMD:

  • The most common form with geographic atrophy (GA) is the advanced stage of dry AMD.
  • No effective treatment is available. Antioxidants like lutein and zeoxanthine are given as prophylaxis.

Wet (exudative, neovascular) AMD:

  • It is much less common than dry but is associated with more rapid progression to advanced sight loss.
  • It is characterized by retinal pigment epithelial detachment and choroidal/subretinal neovascularization.
  • Treatment depends on the location of the choroidal neovascularization membrane.
    • For extrafoveal membrane – laser photocoagulation
    • For subfoveal and juxta foveal treatment options are as follows:
      1. Intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF
      2. Photodynamic therapy – dye used is verteporfin followed by exposure to light from the diode
      3. Transpupillary thermotherapy

 

Image given below is a simulation showing what the grocery store looks like to a patient with age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

 

Image given below depicts the Amsler grid pattern in patients with age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient came with complaints of a sudden decreased vision in both eyes and pain while moving his eyeballs. On examination, vision in both eyes is 3/60. He finds it difficult to read Ishihara’s chart.  Fundus examination showed normal discs and vessels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of retrobulbar neuritis. The normal optic disc is an important pointer toward retrobulbar neuritis.

Optic neuritis is of three types, based on the appearance of optic disc on fundoscopy:

  • Retrobulbar neuritis - Normal optic disc because optic nerve head is not involved.
  • Papillitis - Hyperemic and edematous disc with peripapillary flame-shaped hemorrhages.
  • Neuroretinitis - Macular star appearance due to involvement of nerve fiber layer (NFL)

The clinical features of retrobulbar neuritis include sudden painful vision loss, decreased color contrast sensitivity, Marcus Gunn pupil and pain on movement of eyeballs.

Demyelinating disorders like multiple sclerosis are the most common cause of retrobulbar neuritis.

Steroids are the mainstay of treatment for such demyelinating causes.

Option A: Eale's disease is characterized by recurrent vitreous hemorrhages. Due to this, the fundoscopic findings will not be normal. It is a type of hypersensitivity reaction to tubercular proteins. This causes periphlebitis leading to hemorrhages.

Option B: Papilloedema is swelling of the optic nerve head due to raised intracranial pressure (ICP). Here also the optic disc would not be normal. The patient will have symptoms of raised ICP such as headache, nausea, deterioration of consciousness, etc.

Option D: Papillitis will have an abnormal optic disc as described above.

questions.text: A patient with lepromatous leprosy presents with eye pain. The image of his eye is given below. Identify the finding marked by the arrow:
questions.solution:
The finding marked by the arrow in the image of the eye of a patient with lepromatous leprosy is the iris pearl, which is a pathognomonic finding of leprosy.

Leprosy or Hansen disease is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by infection with Mycobacterium leprae. Ocular features in leprosy occur due to bacterial invasion. They include the following:

  • Keratitis with thickened, beaded corneal nerves, punctate subepithelial lesions, pannus, and vascularization
  • Chronic low-grade anterior uveitis
  • Miosis
  • Iris atrophy
  • Iris pearls 
  • Retinal pearls
  • Other features are scleritis, episcleritis, cataracts, diminished corneal sensation, etc. 

Other options:

Option A: Brushfield spots refer to small white speckles on the peripheral iris that are arranged in a concentric ring. They are seen in Down’s syndrome and may sometimes be a normal finding in blue eyes. The image below shows Brushfield spots.

Option C: Lisch nodules are small well-defined nodules that are seen in neurofibromatosis. They are present bilaterally and appear as clear, yellow, or brown elevations above the iris surface.

Option D: Busacca nodules are present on the iris stroma. They are seen in granulomatous uveitis.

The image below shows Koeppe nodules. These are present at the pupillary border and are seen in anterior uveitis.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis presented with mild irritation in her left eye. The ocular examination revealed a necrotic scleral plaque as shown below. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is a necrotising scleritis without inflammation
It is associated with connective tissue diseases.

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. Spontaneous perforation occurs rarely in this condition as the integrity is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of necrotizing scleritis without inflammation, characterized by progressive scleral thinning. It is typically seen in elderly women with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis. It presents with mild irritation of the eyes. It is a painless condition and has no visual defects. On examination, necrotic scleral plaques may be seen near the limbus, which may coalesce and enlarge. 

It is also associated with other systemic diseases, especially connective tissue diseases. The associated collagen disorders are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis

Medical management includes steroids and immunosuppressants. In severe cases, surgical treatment by scleral patch graft may be done. 

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

Related Pearl: The 'most commons' of rheumatoid arthritis

Feature of RA Most common  
Involved joints MCP, Wrist, PIP(DIP spared) 
Spine involvement Cervical spine
Extra-articular manifestation Subcutaneous nodules (mostly extensor surface)
Cardiac manifestation Pericarditis
Valvular abnormality Mitral regurgitation
Pulmonary manifestation Pleuritis
Hematological manifestation Normochromic normocytic anemia
Neurological manifestation Compression neuropathies (mostly carpal tunnel syndrome)
Ocular manifestation  Keratoconjunctivitis sicca
Lymphoma Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
Cause of death Cardiovascular disease (coronary artery disease)

 

 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with seizures, mental retardation, and port-wine stain. The CT scan of the brain shows characteristic tram track shaped cortical calcifications. Which is the most common ocular manifestation seen in this type of patient?
questions.solution:
The given condition is Sturge-Weber syndrome and glaucoma is the most common ocular manifestation seen in these patients.

Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) is a rare congenital vascular disorder characterized by facial capillary malformation (port-wine stain) and associated capillary-venous malformations affecting the brain and eye.

Ocular manifestations:

  • Glaucoma — The predominant ocular abnormality of SWS is glaucoma (increased intraocular pressure), which occurs in 30 to 70 percent of affected patients.
  • Visual field defects — Many patients have visual field defects, typically homonymous hemianopia. This is due to the presence of a leptomeningeal capillary-venous malformation affecting one or both occipital lobes or optic tracts.
  • Capillary — Venous malformation of the choroid.
  • Heterochromia of the iris
  • Episcleral and conjunctival lesions.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with new-onset discomfort in his left eye for the last two weeks. He has been using contact lenses for the last three years and recalls two episodes recently when he had showered with his lenses on. He complains of tearing, photophobia, and foreign body sensation in the left eye.  Eye examination findings are given below. Which of the following agents is most useful in the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a ring lesion (stromal infiltrate) of acanthamoeba keratitis and among the above polyhexamethyl biguanide (PHMB) 0.02% is the is most useful in the treatment for this condition

Acanthamoeba is a free-living amoeba. It exists as a trophozoite form and resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infectious. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia). Human beings acquire by inhalation of cyst or trophozoite, ingestion of cysts, or through traumatized skin or eyes. It presents as two chronic conditions - acanthamoeba keratitis and granulomatous amoebic encephalitis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis

  • Rare protozoal infection of the cornea
  • Occurs in soft contact lens users who wash their lens with tap water
  • Pain is disproportionate to the degree of keratitis due to perineural invasion.
  • Presents as
    • Ring lesion (most common): Ring stromal infiltrates lead to ring stromal abscess
    • Pseudo-dendrites
    • Reticular pattern

Diagnosis:

  • Confocal Microscopy- may reveal bright trophozoites with pseudopodia in the basal epithelium and double-walled cyst forms
  • Staining: Calcofluor white, acridine orange, lactophenol blue
  • Histopathology- double-walled cysts are seen on H&E. Other stains for Acanthamoeba include calcofluor white, acridic orange, Giemsa-Wright, Wheatly trichrome or periodic acid-Schiff.
  • Culture: Acanthamoeba can be grown on a bed of E. Coli plated on a non-nutrient agar.

 Treatments for this condition include:

  • Polyhexamethyl biguanide (PHMB) 0.02%
  • Chlorhexidine 0.02%
  • Propamidine isothionate (0.1%)
  • Hexamidine
  • Neomycin
  • Paromomycin
  • Clotrimazole
  • Miconazole

All of these treatments are effective if administered by the topical route. Combination therapy can be administered, which includes PHMB with chlorhexidine, or either of these in combination with hexamidine or propamidine. Debridement may be warranted in certain conditions.

Chronic refractory cases may require corneal transplantation and unresponsive cases might need to be managed with enucleation. 

Fluorometholone 0.5% (Option-A) is a treatment option for marginal keratitis which is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction against staphylococcal exotoxins which causes subepithelial marginal infiltrates.

Topical cyclosporine 1% (Option-B) is a treatment option for Mooren's ulcer which is an autoimmune disease characterized by peripheral corneal stromal ulceration with subsequent central spread.

Doxycycline (Option-C) is a treatment option for ocular rosacea which may have corneal manifestations that include epithelial erosions, marginal keratitis, corneal thinning and perforation.

The first image shows double-walled cysts of acanthamoeba in normal H&E staining in a patient with advanced brain disease. The second image depicts the cysts of acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining. The third image shows the corneal scrapings with multiple cysts wall of acanthamoeba on a plain mount.

questions.text: A 68-year-old diabetic male patient presented with complaints of diminished vision. The optical coherence tomography (OCT) image is given below. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen on fundus fluorescein angiography of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces are suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME). Fundus fluorescein angiography image is likely to show a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) in CME.

CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. A petaloid pattern is seen due to dye accumulation in microcystic spaces in the outer plexiform layer.

Common causes of CME include uveitis, previous cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, retinitis pigmentosa, retinopathy of prematurity and topical prostaglandins. Macular edema and cysts may also occur due to niacin toxicity (vitamin B3).

Clinical features in the initial stage include minimal to moderate vision loss. Usually, there are no other associated symptoms. In case of persistent edema, permanent vision loss may occur.

OCT reveals a loss of the foveal depression, thickening of the retina and multiple cystoid areas in the sensory retina. On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  "honeycomb appearance". Optic disc swelling may be seen in some cases. A lamellar hole may occur in long-standing cases.

The image below shows the flower petal pattern in CME.

 

Other options:

Option B: A smokestack appearance is a small hyperfluorescent spot that ascends vertically like a smokestack that looks like an umbrella or a mushroom. It is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR)

 

Option C: Stars in sky appearance is seen in drusens

 

Option D: Inkblot pattern or enlarging dot appearance is a small hyperfluorescent spot that gradually enlarges in size. It is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR)

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the ophthalmologist for evaluation of double vision and deviation of the right eye. The instrument shown below is used for examining this patient. Which of the following tests will not give additional information regarding this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a synoptophore. Binocular single vision is tested by a synoptophore. This patient is most likely suffering from strabismus and the Fincham test will not provide additional information in this patient.

Binocular single vision is the state of simultaneous vision, which is achieved by the coordinated use of both eyes, so that separate and slightly dissimilar images arising in each eye are appreciated as a single image by the process of fusion.

The synoptophore compensates for the angle of squint and allows stimuli to be presented to both eyes simultaneously. It can thus be used to investigate the potential for binocular function in the presence of a manifest squint and is of particular value in assessing young children (from age 3 years), who generally find the test process enjoyable. It can also detect suppression.

Binocular vision can be graded using a synoptophore.

Hirschberg Test:

It gives a rough estimate of the angle of manifest strabismus. A pen torch is used to shine light from an arm's distance and the patient is asked to fixate. The corneal reflection of the light will be decentered in the squinting eye in the direction opposite to the deviation.

Kimsky Test:

It involves the placement of prisms in front of the fixating eye until the corneal light reflections are symmetrical. This gives an approximation of the angle of manifest deviation in strabismus. 

Maddox Wing Test:

It dissociates the eye for near fixation and measures heterophoria. 

 

Note:

Fincham Test is done to evaluate colored halos in cataract and distinguish it from glaucomatous degeneration.

Related Pearl: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo

The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

Related Pearl: Cover tests in ophthalmology

Cover–uncover test:

  • To detect the presence of heterophoria: Latent squint
  • One eye is covered with the occluder, and the other eye is made to fix an object.
  • In the presence of heterophoria, the eye under the cover will deviate.
  • When the cover is removed, the eye under the cover will return back to its normal.
  • This movement is observed.
  • The direction of movement determines the type of heterophoria.

Direct Cover test:

  • Confirms the presence of manifest squint.
  • Differentiates apparent squint from a manifest squint.
  • The patient is asked to fixate on the point light.
  • The normal-looking eye is covered.
  • In manifest squint, the uncovered eye will move in the opposite direction to take fixation.
  • In apparent squint, there will be no movement of the uncovered eye.

Alternate cover test:

  • In the below image, the patient has right exotropia with left eye fixating.
  • Both eyes move each time the cover alternates from one eye to the other.
  • It reveals if the squint is unilateral or alternate.
  • It differentiates between concomitant and paralytic squint.

questions.text:
An ophthalmic surgeon while performing surgery removes all the contents of an eyeball and leaves only a 3 mm frill of the sclera around the optic nerve. Which of the following is an indication for this procedure?
  1. Retinoblastoma
  2. Bleeding anterior staphyloma
  3. Expulsive choroidal hemorrhage
  4. Malignant melanoma
  5. Unresponsive orbital mucormycosis
questions.solution:
The surgery, which is being performed here is a frill evisceration operation which is indicated in bleeding anterior staphyloma and expulsive choroidal hemorrhage.

Evisceration operation:

It is the removal of the contents of the eyeball leaving behind the sclera. Frill evisceration is preferred over simple evisceration. In this, only about 3mm frill of the sclera is left around the optic nerve.

Indications of evisceration

  • Panophthalmitis
  • Expulsive choroidal hemorrhage
  • Bleeding anterior staphyloma

Enucleation operation: It is the complete excision of an eyeball.

Absolute indications are:

  • Retinoblastoma (Option 1)
  • Malignant melanoma (Option 4)

Note: Indication for eye donation: Removal of eyes from the cadaver is presently the most common indication for enucleation.

Exenteration is a mutilating surgery in which all contents of the orbits along with periorbita are removed. It is indicated for malignant tumors arising from the orbital structures or spreading from the eyeball. Orbital mucormycosis (Option 5) is a rare indication of exenteration, particularly in unresponsive cases.

questions.text: While performing the following procedure on a 35-year-old man, at a distance of 1 meter, you find that the red reflex was moving against the movement of the instrument. How will you interpret your findings?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the procedure of retinoscopy (skiascopy) being performed. Since the red reflex moves against the movement of the retinoscope, the patient is interpreted as having myopia of more than 1D.

Interpretation of retinoscopy done at 1 m is as follows:

  • No movement of red reflex - Myopia of 1D
  • With the movement - Emmetropia, hypermetropia, myopia less than 1D
  • Against the movement - Myopia more than 1D

Retinoscopy is an objective method of finding out the refractive error by the method of neutralization.

The patient is made to sit in a dark room, and light is directed onto the patient's eye. If a cycloplegic has been used, the patient can look directly into the light and have the refraction assessed along the actual visual axis.

Neutralization: When the red reflex moves with or against the movement of the retinoscope, we do not exactly know the measure of refractive error. Therefore, to estimate the degree of refractive error, the movement of the red reflex is neutralized by the addition of increasingly convex (+) spherical lenses (when the red reflex was moving with the movement of the retinoscope) or concave (-) spherical lenses (when the red reflex was moving against the movement of the retinoscope).

questions.text: A 22-year-old girl enquires if there are any surgical options for the correction of her myopia. She does not wish to wear her glasses or switch to contact lenses. What is the minimum time frame for which her refractive error has to be stable before laser assisted in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK) can be considered?
questions.solution:
The patient's refractive error has to be stable for a minimum period of at least 1 year before undergoing laser-assisted in-situ keratomileusis. (LASIK).

Myopia also known as shortsightedness is a refractive error in which parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused in front of the retina with the accommodation at rest. 

Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is performed using excimer laser. It is the commonly done surgery for myopia. Excimer laser beam reshapes the cornea by ablating the superficial stroma to a predetermined extent after lifting a flap of the cornea with a sharp microkeratome. 

Patient selection criteria:

  • In individuals aged 21 years and above.
  • In individuals who have a stable refractive error for at least 1 year.
  • In individuals who have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment.
  • In individuals in whom corneal-thinning disorders such as keratoconus have been ruled out.

Complications:

  • Tear instability (dry eye)
  • Wrinkling, distortion, or dislocation of the flap
  • Subepithelial haze with resultant glare, especially at night.
  • Persistent epithelial defects.
  • Epithelial ingrowth under the flap.
  • Diffuse lamellar keratitis (sands of the Sahara)
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Keratoconus

questions.text: Which of the following nerve injury causes neurotrophic keratopathy?
questions.solution:
Neurotrophic keratopathy is due to loss of trigeminal nerve innervation resulting in partial or complete loss of sensation.

Causes:

  • Trigeminal ganglion surgical ablation for neuralgia
  • Stroke
  • Tumour
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Herpes simplex and herpes zoster keratitis (sectoral sensation loss)

Stages:

Stage 1: intrapalpebral epithelial irregularity, oedema and tiny focal deficits

Stage 2: Large persistent epithelial defects with rolled and thickened edges, assuming a punched out configuration

Stage 3: Stromal melting

Treatment: Topical lubricants, protection of the ocular surface with tarsorrhaphy, therapeutic silicone contact lenses, amniotic membrane patching.

 

Exposure keratopathy is caused by paralysis of the facial nerve.  

Exposure keratopathy

  • It is the result of incomplete lid closure (lagophthalmos), with the drying of the cornea despite normal tear production.
  • Causes 
    • Neuroparalytic, e.g., facial nerve palsy
    • Reduced muscle tone as in parkinsonism
    • Mechanical such as lid scarring
    • Proptosis

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman was diagnosed with clinically significant macular edema secondary to non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy and was treated with pan-retinal photocoagulation. Despite this, she did not find any improvement in her symptoms. OCT was done and it showed vitreomacular traction with elevated fovea. What is the next best step in her management?

OCT: Ocular coherence tomography
questions.solution:
Pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) with the removal of the posterior hyaloid is the preferred management in diabetic macular edema with traction. 

Diabetic maculopathy or macular edema is characterized by the accumulation of excess fluid in the subretinal space. It can develop at any stage of diabetic retinopathy (DR), from mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) to proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). 

Clinically significant macular edema (CSME) is diagnosed when one of the following three are present on the slit lamp examination: 

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 microns of the foveal center
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 microns of the foveal center along with adjacent retinal thickening
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening ≥ 1 disc diameter, at least a part of which is within one disc diameter of the foveal center

For diagnosis and further deciding the treatment plan for the patients, OCT is routinely followed. It classifies DME into: 

  • Non-tractional variants are seen in cystoid macular edema, and spongy thickening of the macula, and are managed conservatively
  • Tractional DME has vitreomacular traction or thickened posterior hyaloid and is managed by surgical intervention

In vitreomacular traction, fibrovascular components leak from the vessels into the vitreous cavity and form fibrous bands. It increases the risk of tractional retinal detachment and can rapidly progress into stage 4 diabetic retinopathy.

Thus, surgical management by pars plana vitrectomy with removal of posterior hyaloid is indicated. Scleral buckling and internal tamponade with PPV are also done if the detachment includes the retina. 

The image below is of an OCT in a normal patient. 

The image below is an OCT showing vitreomacular traction. The fovea is elevated from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), as indicated by the arrows. Pseudocysts and retinal morphology distortion can also be seen at the site of traction.

Focal laser photocoagulation and pan-retinal photocoagulation are done in progressive diabetic retinopathy. They are contraindicated in tractional DME due to the risk of further injuries. Anti-VEGF agents like bevacizumab are not effective in vitreomacular traction.  

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presents with complaints of unilateral blurring of vision and photophobia. On fundoscopic examination, the following picture is seen. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The characteristic “headlight in the fog” appearance is suggestive of Toxoplasmosis. It is called so because of the white inflammatory retinal nidus appearing as a headlight when viewed through an inflamed vitreous that resembles a fog.

Ocular toxoplasmosis

  • Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular protozoan.
  • The cat is the definitive host, with intermediate hosts including mice, livestock, birds, and humans.
  • Ocular features
    • Toxoplasmosis constitutes 20–60% of all cases of posterior uveitis in immunocompetent individuals.
    • Reactivation at previously inactive cyst-containing scars is the rule in the immunocompetent.
    • A single inflammatory focus of fluffy white retinitis or retinochoroiditis associated with a pigmented scar ("satellite lesion") is typical.
    • "Headlight in the fog" is the classic description of a white retinal inflammatory nidus viewed through vitritis.
    • "Spill-over" anterior uveitis is common.
  • Treatment
    • Prednisolone (1 mg/kg) is given initially and tapered according to clinical response
    • Pyrimethamine is a folic acid antagonist, is administered as a loading dose of 75–100 mg for 1–2 days followed by 25–50 mg daily for 4 weeks in combination with oral folinic (not folic) acid 5 mg three times a week to retard thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, and folate deficiency.
    • Sulfadiazine 1 g four times daily for 3–4 weeks is usually given in combination with pyrimethamine.
    • Intravitreal therapy with clindamycin (1 mg) and dexamethasone (400 μg) may be as effective as triple therapy in reactivated infection.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition seen in the image?

choices.text: The causative agent is a diplobacillus
Blepharitis is usually not associated with this condition
The mode of spread is from the nasal cavity to eyes
1% tetracycline ointment is used in the treatment

questions.solution:
The condition seen in the given image is angular conjunctivitis. Blepharitis is an associated feature in chronic angular conjunctivitis.

The following findings in the given image are indicative of angular conjunctivitis

  • Reddening of the conjunctiva limited exclusively to the intermarginal strip (especially at the canthus)
  • Excoriation of the skin at the inner and outer palpebral angles

Angular conjunctivitis is a chronic infection caused by Moraxella lacunata, a gram-negative diplobacillus. The bacilli produce a proteolytic fragment which macerates the conjunctival epithelium. The nasal cavity is usually a source of infection, spread through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs.

Distinct clinical features of angular conjunctivitis are as follows:

  • Collection of dirty white foamy discharge at the angles of the eye
  • Conjunctival congestion limited to the intermarginal strip
  • Excoriation of the nearby skin at palpebral angles
  • Associated with blepharitis in chronic infection
  • Shallow marginal corneal ulcers and hypopyon (rare presentation)

Treatment includes application of the tetracycline ointment 2 to 3 times a day for 7 to 14 days.
