questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening pain, redness in the right eye for the last two days. She has a history of sarcoidosis. On examination, the right eye is inflamed around the cornea, the pupil is constricted, and reacts sluggishly to light. The iris appears muddy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with progressively worsening eye pain and redness, constricted pupil reacting sluggishly to light, muddy iris, and a history of sarcoidosis is likely to have anterior uveitis. 

Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disorder characterized by the formation of non-caseating granulomas. Anterior uveitis is often a presenting symptom of sarcoidosis.

Anterior uveitis presents with blurred vision, pain, photophobia, circumcorneal conjunctival injection (around the limbus) with an aqueous flare and keratin precipitates. The pupil is constricted and reacts sluggishly to light. The clear pattern of the iris is lost and it appears muddy.

Slit-lamp examination shows the following signs in anterior uveitis:

Corneal signs: 

  • Keratic precipitates

Anterior chamber signs: 

  • Hypopyon
  • Aqueous cells
  • Aqueous flare
  • Deep and irregular anterior chamber due to posterior synechiae

Iris signs: 

  • Loss of normal pattern
  • Change in color "muddy iris"
  • Posterior synechiae

Pupillary signs: 

  • Constricted pupil
  • Irregular pupil shape
  • Ectropion of uveal pigment
  • Occlusion pupillae - blocked pupil due to extensive exudate

Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of management for uveitis.

Cycloplegics

  • atropine
  • Relieves spasm of iris sphincter and ciliary muscle
  • Prevents the formation of synechiae

Steroids reduce inflammation by their anti-inflammatory effect 

Systemic therapy 

  • Steroids
  • NSAIDs
  • Immunosuppressants
    • Used in severe cases

Other options:

Option A: Acute bacterial conjunctivitis presents with pain, irritation, photophobia with hyperemia (pink eye), and purulent exudate. There is a diffuse conjunctival injection which is less seen in the circum-corneal region (as opposed to anterior uveitis)

Option C: Endophthalmitis is the infection of the intra-ocular cavities which presents with severe pain, loss of vision, and lid edema. It is usually seen in post-operative cases of ocular trauma (exogenous) and patients hospitalized with severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections (endogenous).

Option D: Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma presents with severe unilateral eye pain, associated with headache and loss of vision. The examination shows a red congested eye, corneal edema with a shallow anterior chamber, and a mid-dilated pupil.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The given image is that of an enucleation spoon. This is identified by the central cleavage that engages the optic nerve in enucleation.

 

Other options:

Option A- Evisceration spatula consists of a small but stout rectangular blade with a slightly convex surface and blunt edges attached to a handle. It is used to separate out the uveal tissue from the sclera during evisceration operation.

 

Option C- Chalazion clamp consists of two limbs like forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. The tip of one limb is flattened in the
form of a round disc while the tip of the other arm has a small circular ring. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and curettage operation.

 

Option D- Bone punch consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle. It is used to enlarge the bony opening during
dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening.

questions.text: The wrong statement about the given image is :

choices.text: At point A vertical rays are converging more rapidly than horizontal rays.
At point B - Vertical rays have come to a focus, while horizontal rays are still converging, so it will be a horizontal straight line
At point C the horizontal rays are diverging and vertical rays are converging
Point D is the circle of least confusion.

questions.solution:
The given image shows a sturm’s conoid.

The vertical rays are diverging and horizontal rays are still converging at point C.

  • Horizontal oval is formed because vertical rays are converging more rapidly than horizontal at point A.
  • Vertical rays have come to a focus, while horizontal rays are still converging, so it will be a horizontal straight line at point B
  • Vertical rays are diverging and horizontal rays are still converging at points C, D and E.
  • Vertical rays have diverged as much as the horizontal rays have converged at point D, so we get a perfect circle called circle of least confusion. At this point, the divergence of vertical rays is exactly equal to the convergence of the horizontal rays from the axis.
  • At point E - Vertical oval
  • At point F - vertical straight line
  • At point G and beyond - Both rays are diverging and we always get a vertical oval / prolate ellipse.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old female patient presents with diminished vision, headache, and eye pain. She had a history of herpes infection. On examination, there is an increase in IOP. The ophthalmologist prescribes an eye drop for increased IOP. After a week, the patient presents with herpetic keratitis. Which of the following is the most likely drug to have favored the development of herpetic keratitis?

(IOP- Intraocular pressure)
questions.solution:
Latanoprost is the most likely drug to have favored the development of herpetic keratitis in this patient.

Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analogue and acts by increasing the uveoscleral outflow thus reducing the IOP. Latanoprost is preferred over β-blockers due to its decreased systemic side effects. 

Prostaglandin analogues induce the release of endogenous prostaglandins in the iris and ciliary which enhances the cell-to-cell spread of HSV resulting in reactivation of the herpes infection. 

Adverse effects:

  • conjunctival hyperaemia
  • eyelash thickening 
  • iris pigmentation 
  • promotion of herpetic keratitis in a patient with a history of herpes infection
  • if used preoperatively, cystoid macular edema following cataract surgery

Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is a bilateral, symmetrical disease with an adult-onset type. In this condition, there is an increase in the IOP due to trabecular sclerosis leading to decreased aqueous outflow. The clinical features include headache, difficulty in dark adaptation, frequent change of glasses, and blurring of vision. 

On ocular examination, an open anterior chamber angle, glaucomatous optic nerve head changes, visual field defects, and an increased IOP of more than 21mmHg are noted.

Other options:

Option A- Timolol is a non-selective β-blocker that decreases the IOP by reducing the aqueous humor production through blockade of the β-receptors on the ciliary epithelium. The adverse effects include:

  • Ocular effects are allergy, decreased corneal sensation, and punctate keratitis
  • Systemic effects-
    • Potentially fatal bronchospasm in asthmatic patients and reversible airway diseases due to blockade of β2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle
    • Heart blocks, bradycardia, worsening of heart failure, and hypotension are some of the cardiovascular adverse effects

Option C- Brimonidine is a selective alpha-2 agonist which decreases aqueous synthesis and increases uveoscleral outflow. It can cross the blood-brain barrier and, hence, causes drowsiness and CNS depression. It is contraindicated in infants and children.

Option D- Dorzolamide is a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that decreases IOP by reducing aqueous formation. The main adverse effect is the bitter taste following administration. It is contraindicated in people with allergies to sulfonamide antibiotics.

questions.text: Knudson's two-hit hypothesis describes the occurrence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Knudson's two-hit hypothesis describes the occurrence of retinoblastoma.

Knudson's hypothesis can be stated as follows:

  • Two mutations (hits), involving both alleles of RB are required to produce retinoblastoma.
  • In familial retinoblastoma, one of the pair of alleles of RB1 is mutated in all the cells of the body. When a further mutagenic event ("second hit" according to the "two-hit" hypothesis proposed by Knudson) affects the second allele, the cell may then undergo malignant transformation. A large majority of these children develop bilateral and multifocal tumors.
  • In sporadic cases, both RB alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same retinoblast (two hits).

Familial retinoblastoma patients also have a predisposition to non-ocular cancers because of the presence of the mutation in all cells, such as pinealoblastoma (usually before the age of 5 years), osteosarcomas, soft tissue sarcomas, and melanomas.

Note:

Trilateral retinoblastoma = Pinealoblastoma + Bilateral retinoblastoma

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents with a history of injury to the eye caused while climbing a tree 5 days ago; the injury has caused pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. Slit-lamp examination reveals a lesion as shown below. Which of the following is a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image of an ulcer with irregular feathery margins are suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer. Satellite lesions are a feature of fungal ulcers.

A fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter. Signs are more pronounced than symptoms. The corneal ulcer appears dry.

Causative organisms:

  • Aspergillus
  • Fusarium
  • Candida albicans

Signs of a fungal ulcer:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley ring) may be seen around the ulcer due to the deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, and immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.

Treatment:

  • Topical drugs: These include topical natamycin, voriconazole, or amphotericin B drops, which are effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium. Nystatin is effective against Candida.
  • Systemic drugs: Severe ulcers with hypopyon, perforation, or suspected endophthalmitis might warrant the use of oral antifungal agents such as ketoconazole or voriconazole.

Other options :

Option A: Reverse hypopyon is the collection of emulsified silicone oil in the anterior chamber. Here, emulsified silicone bubbles are coalesced and seen in the upper part of the anterior chamber (AC). 

Option B: Dendritic ulcer is seen in epithelial keratitis caused by the herpes simplex virus. An image of a dendritic ulcer with fluorescein dye is shown below.

Option C: Ring abscess is seen in helminthic keratitis, especially that caused by Acanthamoeba. Gradual enlargement and coalescence of infiltrates occur, leading to the formation of an abscess.

questions.text: While examining the visual fields in a 52-year-old male in the ophthalmology OPD, You noticed that the patient is unable to see the upper fourth portions of the same side of his superior visual field. Such visual field defects are seen in which of the following lesions?
questions.solution:
The "Pie in the sky" field defect refers to superior quadrantic hemianopia due to the involvement of the inferior fibers of the optic radiations in the temporal lobe (Meyer’s loop).

The term "pie in the floor" defects refers to inferior quadrantic hemianopia. They are produced when the superior fibers of the optic radiations in the parietal lobe (Baum's loop) are involved.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following fundoscopic findings according to the respective grades in which they are seen, as per Keith Wagener Barker (KWB) grading of hypertensive retinopathy, starting with grade 1.
  1. Macular star
  2. Optic Disc swelling
  3. Retinal arteriolar narrowing 
  4. Arteriovenous nipping
questions.solution:
The correct sequence according Keith Wagener Barker (KWB) grading of hypertensive retinopathy is

3. Retinal arteriolar narrowing 

4. Arteriovenous nipping

1. Macular star

2. Optic Disc swelling

Keith Wagener Barker (KWB) grading of hypertensive retinopathy:

Grade 1: Presence of mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing. 

Grade 2: Presence of focal arteriolar narrowing and arteriovenous nipping.

  • Copper wiring: Opacified appearance of arteriolar walls.
  • Salus’s sign: Deflection of retinal vein as it crosses the arteriole.
  • Gunn’s sign: Tapering of the retinal vein on either side of the AV crossing.
  • Bonnet’s sign: Banking of the retinal vein distal to the AV crossing.

Grade 3: Grade 2 plus retinal hemorrhages, exudates and macular star.

  • Retinal hemorrhages:
    • Dot-blot hemorrhages: Bleeding in the inner retinal layer
    • Flame shaped hemorrhage: Bleeding is in the superficial retinal layer
  • Retinal exudates:
    • Hard exudates: Lipid deposits in the retina
    • Soft exudates: These are also known as cotton wool spots which appear due to ischemia of the nerve fibers
  • Macular Changes
    • Macular star formation due to deposition of hard exudates around the macula.

Grade 4: Severe grade 3 plus optic disc swelling. This is a marker of malignant hypertension.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents to the refraction room where you are posted as an intern. You read his previous prescription which mentions blurred vision and eye strain due to 'astigmatism'. What is the type of his astigmatism, if the horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian?
questions.solution:
The horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian in Against-the-rule astigmatism (ATR)

Few definitions:

With the rule, astigmatism: The vertical meridian is rendered more curved due to the pressure of the eyelids. It is normally seen in the eyes.

Oblique astigmatism: Here, the two principal meridians are not the horizontal and vertical meridians although they are at right angles to each other.

Bi-oblique astigmatism: Here, the two principal meridians are not at right angles to each other; for example, one may be at 40 degrees and the other, at 100 degrees.

questions.text: Which of the following actions is examined and what is the defect observed in a patient with abducens nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle. The action produced by this muscle is abduction. The sixth cranial nerve palsy results in an esotropia/convergent squint.

The outward movement (abduction) of the affected eye is impaired, and the face will be turned towards the same side. When the patient looks at the paralyzed side, they will experience homonymous diplopia. 

Esotropia can be revealed using the cover-uncover test. 

First, the patient has to fix their gaze by looking at a distant object. One of the eyes is covered while simultaneously observing the other eye. If the other eye moves away from the nose, then esotropia is present. This procedure should be repeated on the other eye. 

 

The occulomotor nerve supplies all extraocular muscles except:

  • Lateral rectus, which is supplied by the 6th nerve
  • Superior oblique, which is supplied by the 4th nerve

questions.text: Among the following, which muscle is affected first in cavernous sinus thrombosis?
questions.solution:
The first muscle to be affected in cavernous sinus thrombosis is the lateral rectus.

Ophthalmoplegia in cavernous sinus thrombosis occurs in the following sequence:

  • 6th nerve palsy (lateral rectus palsy) occurring first of all as it passes through the cavernous sinus.
  • 3rd and 4th nerves are involved later as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with left eyelid swelling for the past two days and denies any history of ocular trauma. He reports that he had a mild flu-like illness one week back for which he took some medications. He is febrile. Ophthalmic examination reveals normal visual acuity with no ophthalmoplegia and no proptosis.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with eyelid swelling and fever following an infection without proptosis, and ophthalmoplegia with normal visual acuity are suggestive of preseptal cellulitis/ periorbital cellulitis.

Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the subcutaneous tissues anterior to the orbital septum. The commonly implicated bacteria include Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes.

The mode of spread of infection can occur through skin trauma, insect bites, acute hordeolum, dacryocystitis, conjunctivitis, sinusitis, Upper respiratory tract infection, and middle ear infection.

Clinical features include,

  • Tender, firm, erythematous eyelid swelling
  • Conjunctiva - usually no chemosis
  • Proptosis - absent
  • Ocular movements - normal
  • Visual acuity - normal
  • Systemic symptoms: fever, leucocytosis

Treatment: 

  • Antibiotics - oral or i.v depending on severity.
  • Systemic analgesics
  • Warm compresses

Complications include spread of infection and may develop into orbital cellulitis, abscess formation, meningitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Option A:  Endophthalmitis is the inflammation of the inner coats of the eye due to intraocular colonization of infectious agents. There is exudation within intraocular fluids. It generally occurs after trauma, surgery, or due to an endogenous source. It is characterized by poor visual acuity, corneal edema, hypopyon, vitreous inflammation, and poor fundus visualization. 

Option B: Orbital cellulitis refers to the acute infection of the contents of the orbit behind the orbital septum. Features include:

  • Pain, lid edema, erythema, chemosis, and axial proptosis.
  • Increased pain with movement of eyes and ophthalmoplegia (decreased ocular motility) is a classic symptom
  • A rapid loss of vision is due to the involvement of the optic nerve, diplopia.
  • Systemic symptoms include malaise and fever.
